div.sent: The birth of independent Bangladesh is the most important event in the national life of Bangalees.
Bangalees continuously protested and launched movements against the exploitation, suppression and discrimination of Pakistani rulers.
Along with these movements and events, the nationalistic feelings of Bangalees were awakened and their anti-Pakistani sentiments became forceful.
The events from 1947 to 1971 of Pakistani era had a far-reaching impact on our national history.
The crisis of ideology in Pakistan became clear during that period.
Following are some important chapters of the movements and struggles against Pakistan.
This condition could be called crisis of identity.
The principal argument for the creation of Pakistan was that the Hindu and the Muslim were two different nations.
But after independence leaders realized that there were other identities of men besides religion.
Language was one of the identities.
Between the two parts of Pakistan, in East Pakistan most of the people spoke Bangla where in West Pakistan people spoke four different languages.
In spite of making them united by means of Urdu, it was not possible to eliminate the differences of regions and cultures.
They even took a stand against the rich Bangla literature and heritage and tried to belittle famous literary persons like Rabindranath, Modhusudan and Bangkim.
This instead of creating unity, created more conflicts and divisions among the people.
The Bangalee Muslims who struggled hard to establish Pakistan were the first ones to realise that their dreams about the new country had been shattered.
The renowned people of East Pakistan foresaw the ruin of Bangalees because of such steps taken by Pakistani government.
It is not an ideology, rather a fact.
Even after forty years of independence of Bangladesh, Pakistan is still suffering from the same crisis of ideology.
The students of Dhaka University protested saying, no no no.
Educationists, literary personalities, intellectuals and most of the political leaders of this country took stand in favor of Bengali language.
But the Prime Minister Liakot Ali Khan vehemently opposed the proposal.
Unfortunately many Bangalee members of Muslim League took part against the proposal.
But it was rational only for Bangla to be the state language.
The then population of Pakistan was 6 crore and 90 lac of which 4 crore and 40 lac were Bangalee.
However, the rest 2 and a half crore people did not speak Urdu either.
But because their mothertongues were not very advanced, their medium of education was Urdu.
But Bangalees did not propose to make Bangla the only state language rather to give Bangla the status of a state language along with Urdu.
Many initiatives were undertaken in the province to implement the right of Bangla, the mothertongue.
Among these was the All Party State Language Movement Council formed by the liberal and progressive politicians and students of Dhaka University.
Among the student leaders were Kazi Golam Mahbub, Shawkat Ali, Gaziul Huq, Mohammad Toaha, Abdul Matin and Sheikh Mujibur Rahman.
But the movement could not be stopped by suppression and oppression.
The Muslim League government decided to stop students under the leadership of Chief Minister Nurul Amin.
Government declared section 144 within Dhaka University campus which meant that not more than 4 people could bring out a procession on the streets.
But why would the demonstrating students accept that?
They were ready to take any courageous step without any compromise for upholding the dignity and the right of their mother language.
Students the night before the 21st February decided to bring out a procession breaking section 144.
Police swooped on the demonstrating students that day with weapons and arms.
First they charged baton and threw tear gas.
But they failed to control the protestors.
Abdul Matin and Gaziul Huq were leading the procession while police opened fire and killed Rafiq Uddin, Abdul Zabbar and Abul Barkat.
Many were injured.
They were admitted into Dhaka Medical College Hospital.
Abdus Salam died while treatment was going on.
Nine years old young boy Ohiullah was also killed by police firing.
All of them are language martyrs.
On 23rd February a mausoleum was built on the spot where the students were killed.
In 1963, a large mausoleum was built in place of this temporary one.
This is the central Shahid Minar in front of the Dhaka Medical College.
Bangalees protected the dignity of their mothertongue by shedding blood.
At last, the legislature of East Bengal took decision in favor of making Bangla as one of the state languages of Pakistan.
Both Bangla and Urdu attained the dignity of being the state languages of Pakistan.
Bangalees felt proud of Bangla language, Bangla literature and their 1000 years old cultural heritage.
The whole world regards Bangalees with respect for their language movement and sacrifices.
Our Language Movement achieved international recognition in In the same year, on 17 November, UNESCO declared 21st February as the International Mother Language Day.
All the nations now observe 21st February every year to show respect to their own mother languages and to recollect the sacrifice of Bangalees.
Since the very beginning of the creation of Pakistan, the people of East Pakistan had started to feel aggrieved by the conspiracies of the rulers.
People of different opinions started getting united in the question of self protection and development.
The ruling Muslim League became the symbol of conspiracy and suppression.
It was a period of transition in the history of Bangalees.
This alliance was known as United Front.
In the election, United Front gained absolute majority.
Let us now discuss how many parties were there in the United Front.
This election was not for forming the National Council of the country formed by the two parts of the parliament in Pakistan.
It was the election for the legislature of the East Bengal only.The ruling party Muslim League along with16 other parties participated in this election.
But the main competition was held between United Front and Muslim League.
United Front participated with the symbol Boat.
Among the younger leaders, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman attracted the attention of all and became popular.
United Front placed their 21 Points programme before the people.
At that time, Muslims and people of other religions had separate seats and separate elections were held.
All the ministers from the ruling party lost and the party obtained 10 seats only.
This victory of the United Front was termed as the Ballot Revolution by the newspapers and magazines at home and abroad.
This was the first election held in East Bengal where all the adult population cast their votes.
The Bangalees voted for the Boat symbol of the United Front being inspired to protect their rights.
The defeat of Muslim League proved that one could not deceive people for long using religion for oppression.
It also proved that no government could stay in power taking a stand against its people's language and culture, continuing suppression and oppression.
The new spirit of nationalism in Bangalees inspired them of other movements.
On the other hand, the Muslim League came to be known as an anti- people party.
By 1957 this party got divided into multiple factions and finally descended from the rule of Pakistan.
Muslim League did not secure a single seat in 1970s election.
The Reasons behind the Defeat of Muslim League and Victory of United Front The activities of Muslim League after independence began to agitate the Bangalees.
And since the victory of the Language Movement, people's expectation for political changes became stronger.
People of different ideologies and parties joined the United Front.
This was one of the reasons for the easy victory of United Front.
The 21 Point demands were also the reason of the victory of the party.
The United Front was a gathering of matured and experienced as well as young and new leaders.
Moreover, the participation and propaganda of the younger activists were notable.
On the other hand, the activities of Muslim League were confused, inconsistent and lacked transparency.
So the party leaders and workers of Muslim League could not stand before the manifesto and activities of the leaders of the United Front.
The reasons for Muslim League's defeat were their misrule, internal conflicts, corruption and discrimination between the two parts of Pakistan.
Conspiracy of Pakistani rulers never stopped rather continued.
Within two months, the United Front government was dissolved.
A civil government was then formed according to the Constitution of Pakistan.
But Iskandar Mirza declared martial law on 7 October, 1958 on the pretext of lawlessness and disorderly situation in the country.
The activities of all political parties were banned.
The Chief of Army, General Ayub Khan was made the military ruler.
Many Bangalee leaders like Abul Monsur Ahmed and Sheikh Mujibur Rahman were arrested at that time.
Within 20 days, Ayub Khan compelled Iskandar Mirza to resign and leave Pakistan and became the self declared president of Pakistan.
During Ayub Khan's reign, people started to unite and at one stage they started movements against the martial law.
Bangalees never retreated but moved forward despite different oppressions by Ayub Khan.
The streets resounded with protests and demands of the people.
It was the students of East Bengal who first started movements against Ayub Khan.
The Pakistani rulers had created discrimination in education sectors of the two parts of Pakistan.
The educational institutions were inadequate and lewer in number in East Pakistan, and little money was sanctioned for education there.
Politics was forbidden from 1958 to Many leaders were arrested and imprisoned.
Bangalee students came forward to remedy this political crisis.
In 1962, President Ayub Khan made a constitution where democratic desires of Bangalees were shattered.
This constitution kept provision for Presidential form of government with centralized power in the president's hands.
In the middle of 1962 students organized demonstrations and started a movement for cancellation of this constitution.
Students movement against Sharif Commission started gradually spreading across all the institutions in the country.
The government was ultimately compelled to cancel the Sharif Commission in the face of students violent movement.
The people of the then East Pakistan again came onto the streets for their rights.
Sheikh Mujibur Rahman came to lead the movement for the safeguard of the rights of Bangalees.
the legislature or the parliament would be formed with all the adult franchise.
And the government of Pakistan was to implement this.
The elected leaders of East Pakistan would rule their country in their own way.
The central government would hold the responsibility for policy formulation in areas of defense and foreign affairs.
East and West Pakistan would have two different currencies but they could be used easily in both parts.
The provincial governments would hold the power to fix and collect all taxes.
A portion of the collected tax would be deposited to the treasury of the central government.
The foreign exchange earnings of each province should be accounted separately.
The provincial governments would have the right to formulate trade treaty and export- import deals with the rest of the world.
A paramilitary force should be formed separately for East Pakistan.
Ayub Khan became apprehensive of the Six Point Demands because he realized that the exploitation of East Pakistan would end if they gained autonomy.
Besides, they were also apprehensive that East Pakistan might demand independence.
But these export earnings instead of being spent for the development of East Pakistan were diverted to civil and military sectors in West Pakistan.
Bangalees had limited opportunities in higher positions.
With East Pakistan being autonomous, the West Pakistan would not have monopoly to these benefits and privileges.
So the conspiracy against the people of East Pakistan started again.
At that time many cases were filed against Sheikh Mujibur Rahman in different districts of the province.
The government started arresting the leaders of Awami League and filing cases against them.
Sheikh Mujibur Rahman along with Tajuddin Ahmed and other leaders of Awami League was subject to extreme harassments.
But in no way the movement could be suppressed because of the firm leadership of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman and his widespread popular support.
In order to suppress the Six Point Demands, the rulers of Pakistan lodged cases against Sheikh Mujibar Rahman and other leaders for treason.
Some Bangalee army, navy and air force officials were also implicated in it.
Besides, allegations were brought against three top-level Bangalee civilian officials.
In history, it is known as the Agartala Conspiracy Case.
But ultimately, the government was forced to withdraw the case in the face of intense movevement by people and students.
But the rebellious Bangalees were not to be suppressed, and massive movements started.
The students of Dhaka University came forward with a new Eleven Point Movement programme in addition to the Six Point Demand.
The Eleven Point Demand also included some other demands, which were just and right.
These included tax reductions, nationalizing bank, insurance as well as industrial enterprises and releasing political detainees.
The Eleven Point Movement by the students made the spontaneous uprising of the people more wide-spread and stronger.
And an event of police atrocity stimulated the spirit of protesting conscience and the desire for movement among the people.
The deaths of Professor Shamshuzuha in Rajshahi, Sgt.
Zahurul Huq, student-leader Asad and young Matiur in processions turned the movement into a mass uprising.
Ayub Khan was forced on 22 February to withdraw the Agartola Case and to announce the unconditional release of all prisoners.
Remembering his enormous contribution to the nation, we shall always use Bangabandhu before his name.
The mass uprising in 1969 was the strongest movement during the tenure of Ayub Khan.
Even though it was a movement with some general demands, it turned gradually into a struggle for autonomy and for people's rights.
Only within three months this movement spread out beyond Dhaka to the remotest areas of the country.
Through this movement, it was proved that the renaissance and unity of the people was stronger than the bullet of the autocratic rulers.
As a result of this movement, students offered a new generation of leadership to the nation.
The students unity united the politicians too.
Ayub Khan was forced to resign.
In this way the uprising in 1969, through the evolution of the Bangale nationalism, inspired the struggle for liberation.
The mass uprising sharpened the struggling minds of the Bangalees and turned them into a brave nation.
Above all, the mass uprising unified the Bangalees in terms of the thought of sacrifice.
Following all these, the dominance of West Pakistan over East Pakistan came to an end.
The role of the mass uprising of 1969 in the birth of an independent Bangladesh is enormous.
After handing over the official power to Yahya Khan, the Army Chief, Ayub Khan resigned.
Soon after assuming power, with an objective to pacify the Bangalees, Yahya Khan made a commitment to hold a general election.
The road to the creation of an independent Bangladesh was smoothened.
Now let us discuss how and which parties participated in this election.
At that time, Pakistan had two parliaments or houses.
The two parts of Pakistan constituted the National Assembly which had 300 members.
Based on population, 162 seats were allocated to East Pakistan and 138 seats to West Pakistan.
The Provincial Assembly of East Pakistan had 300 seats and the combined for Provincial Assemblies of West Pakistan had 300 seats.
The Government of Pakistan announced the dates of elections for National and Provincial Assemblies 7th December and 17th December respectively.
From the point of view of results, the elections of 1970 were noteworthy.
In the National Assembly, Awami League won 160 seats out of 162 seats allocated for East Pakistan.
Winning 83 seats in West Pakistan, the PPP remained in the second position.
In this case, to form the government, the Awami League needed 151 seats which no other parties of Pakistan had.
In the East Pakistan Provincial Assembly, the Awami League had similar success.
Here the Awami League won 298 seats out of 310 seats and achieved an absolute majority.
The Awami League won no seat in West Pakistan and the PPP did not have any candidate at all in East Pakistan.
In spite of the various efforts by the Pakistan Government, the anti-Awami League parties could not influence the election.
One could now be sure that the Bangalees are a separate nation.
In this election, Awami League dominated in East Pakistan and PPP in West Pakistan.
As a result it was proved that the rule of West Pakistan over East Pakistan was not legitimate.
It was also proved that the long demand of autonomy by Bangalees for so long was also legitimate.
By means of victory in the election, the Awami League and Bangabondhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman became the symbol of emancipation for the Bangalee nation.
After the birth of Pakistan, Pakistani rulers could not think of the Bangalees as one of their own.
As a result, the Bangalees had a new foreign ruler instead of an earlier one.
The relations between the two parts of Pakistan became that of the exploiter and the exploited.
We had become the exploited.
Through widespread disparities in political, administrative, military, economic, educational and cultural arenas, attempts were made to dominate the Bangalees.
But Bangalees protested through various means against these exploitations.
In the end, the Bangalees established a new state through a struggle for liberation.
From the very beginning, the Bangalees were politically discriminated against in the newly created Pakistan, the two parts of which were thousand miles apart.
Even though the majority of the population of Pakistan was Bangalees, the capital city of the new country was established in Karachi instead of Dhaka.
The top positions of the state like the Governor General, Prime Minister, members of cabinet were filled in from West Pakistan.
During the period of 1947-1971, out of 211 central Ministers, only 95 were Bangalees.
During the tenure of Ayub Khan, the number for Bangalee Central Ministers was only 22 out of a total of 62 Central Ministers.
The Bangalee Central Ministers were not given important portfolios.
In 1958, Martial Law was declared.
Under the Martial Law, all political activities, parliamentary programmes and fundamental rights were suspended.
Even though Awami League won the election in 1970, they were not allowed to form the government.
That was why the demand for autonomy within the framework of the statehood of Pakistan turned into a demand for independence for the Bangalees.
In a new developing country, in general, most people liked to join the government services.
If the state created any discrimination or constraint in this process, that would be a violation of fundamental and human rights.
Bangalees, despite their qualifications, were deprived of appropriate posts in administrative sectors.
The Bangalees were not appointed in important ministries like Defense and Foreign Affairs.
In this case, only 23% of Bangalees were appointed in first grade positions.
The same discrimination was made to recruit the Bangalees in various public sector entities like the Central Bank, the Railway and Government corporations.
The discrimination was also maintained in the army, the navy and the air force.
The three headquarters for the defense forces and an ammunition factory were in West Pakistan.
The percentage of Bangalee officers in the military forces was only 5%.
Only 4% of army were Bangalees.
Although the Bangalee recruitment was a little better in the navy and the air force, it was not significant.
The allocation for defense force was 60% of the total national budget and the lion's share of it was spent in West Pakistan.
Discrimination was also evident in the case of promotion.
That was why the issue of defence was seriously considered in the Six Point Demand by the Awami League.
Because of the neglect of the Central Government, the borders of East Pakistan used to be unprotected.
This insecurity of East Pakistan became critically evident during the 1965 war.
Even though Pakistan had more foreign exchange earnings, not more than 21% of such earnings were allocated to East Pakistan.
The province was allocated not more than 34% of foreign aids but Bangalees were to carry the burden of the external loans.
Only 31%, of whatever was imported from abroad was allocated for the development of East Pakistan.
As less resources were allocated for the development of East Pakistan, it experienced insignificant progress.
On the contrary West Pakistan developed through our resources.
Besides, significant amount of resources were transferred from East to West Pakistan.
$2000 million out of export earnings was transferred from East to West during the Pakistani period.
A symbolic poster used at that time to portray the disparities is presented here.
A cow is eating grass in East Pakistan (presently Bangladesh) and Pakistanis are milking the cow.
It means that the production takes place in East Pakistan but the earnings from that are transferred to West Pakistan.
Since the birth of Pakistan, Pakistanis had tried to destroy Bangla language, literature and culture.
In 1948 they tried to impose Urdu as the state language on the Bangalees by force.
Bangalees were to sacrifice their lives in 1952 to establish the right of Bangla language.
Even though the Constitution of 1956 recognised Bangla as the second State Language of Pakistan, the conspiracy against Bangla did not stop there.
At that time the name of East Bengal was changed to East Pakistan.
Attempts to write Bangla in Roman alphabet continued.
There were boundless restrictions not only over movies, dramas, newspapers and books, but broadcasting Tagore songs, celebrating the Bangla New Year were also forbidden.
Thus, different means were used to hurt the cultural activities of Bangalees.
Bangalees are fighters.
Bangalees had protested the injustice during the times of the Mughal and the British.
They never silently tolerated the discriminatory actions of the Pakistan Government.
With the Language Movement, the Bangalees started anti- Pakistan movements.
By defeating the Muslim League in 1954, for the first time, Bangalees got a short-lived opportunity to form the government.
Against the Martial Law of Ayub Khan, the students started anti-Ayub movement through the education movement.
In the decade of the 1960s, through literary conferences and cultural movements, anti-Ayub activities were carried on.
A cultural renaissance started all over the country including Dhaka and Chittagong with the celebration of Bishwa Kabi Rabindranath Tagore's birth centenary.
At the pressure of the mass movement, Ayub Khan was forced to withdraw the Agartala Conspiracy Case and resign.
The Awami League achieved absolute majority in the election of 1970 under the leadership of Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman.
This absolute victory actually led Bangalees towards independence.
But the Pakistani rulers started hatching conspiracies delaying to hand over power and playing different games.
On 25 March in 1971, at midnight, the Pakistani military force all on a sudden attacked and started genocide over unarmed Bangalees.
Bangabandhu was imprisoned on that night but before being arrested he declared the independence of Bangladesh the same night.
The liberation war started.
